close_symbols: definition of bool (stdbool.h or project typedef)
explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required to check for compiler language extensions:

- struct lfs_commit
  - The function uses a designated initializer for a struct lfs_commit instance (e.g. .block = ..., .off = ...). To decide whether this is a compiler extension or standard-language usage we must see the exact struct definition and confirm the initializer targets named fields (standard C99) rather than relying on any compiler-specific extension. The struct layout also shows whether any non‑standard bitfield/attribute declarations are present.

- struct lfs_dir_commit_commit
  - The function uses a compound literal of this type: &(struct lfs_dir_commit_commit){ lfs, &commit }. Determining whether that compound-literal usage is a language extension (vs. standard C99) requires the type definition to check that the syntax matches a plain struct initialization and to ensure no compiler-specific members/attributes are involved.

- typedef lfs_gstate_t (or its struct definition)
  - The code uses aggregate initialization (lfs_gstate_t delta = {0};) and later lfs_gstate_tole32(&delta). To ensure these initializers are standard and not dependent on compiler extensions (e.g. anonymous structs, nonstandard zero-initialization rules), the full type definition is needed.

- definition of bool (stdbool.h or project typedef)
  - The function declares "bool hasdelete = false;". Whether that is standard C (_Bool / stdbool.h) or a project/compiler extension (macro, custom typedef) matters for the MISRA check. Provide the bool definition / inclusion to decide if a language extension is used.

- __STDC_VERSION__
  - Many constructs in the function (designated initializers, compound literals, declaration in for-loop initializers, // comments) are standard only in C99 and later. The value of __STDC_VERSION__ in the build environment determines whether those features are standard or whether they would be treated as compiler extensions. The analyzer needs this macro value.

- __GNUC__, __clang__, _MSC_VER
  - If __STDC_VERSION__ indicates an older standard or is absent, whether the shown constructs are permitted depends on the compiler and its documented extensions. The common compiler identification macros (__GNUC__, __clang__, _MSC_VER) are required so the next agent can consult the compiler’s documentation to decide if a given construct in this function is a documented extension.

Note: The listed symbols are the minimum required to decide whether the syntactic constructs in this function are plain standard-C features or rely on compiler-specific language extensions. Other project macros (e.g. LFS_ASSERT) are not necessary for deciding the presence of language extensions unless they expand to compiler-specific attributes/keywords; if so, include those macro definitions as well.
